July 30, 1952
PRESIDENT
SEYMOUR N. SIEGEL
WNYC, Municipal Broadcasting System
2500 Municipal Building
New York 7, N. Y.
Mr. James Miles
Gregory Hall
University of Illinois
Urbana, Ill,
Dear Mr. Miles:
Congratulations and hosannasl Your letter of July 29th concerning
the operation of the tape duplicator marks a milestone (and I am
not punning) in the history of educational broadcasting. Let’s
hope all troubles are over and the Network can now begin to deliver
a service about which all of us have dreamed for a long time.
The response from the stations on the Jeffersonian Heritage is
encouraging. Approximately 40 stations have indicated specific
broadcast schedules. What is of greater interest is that 39 com¬
mercial stations have already written or called concerning the
availability of the series - all as a result of stories like the
enclosed.
We are looking into the possibility of having the Jefferson series
pressed by the same outfit that turned out THE PEOPLE ACT. We can
have approximately 100 LP sets of 7 records each at a cost of less
than $15. a set. Obviously, if we order additional quantities the
unit cost will drop. If we received $20. or $25. a set from com¬
mercial stations it would provide some slight income to NAEB even
though it would not in any manner attempt to recapture the total
cost of production. I am, of course, basically interested in the
pressings as a means of promotion and it would have to be the
promotional budget which would carry the initial costs. In other
words, a beautifully boxed album of pressings might be presented to
the President at the White House. I find it somewhat difficult
to visualize a presentation of a series of tapes.
